keywords: Understory cover, Percent understory coverage, Vegetation coverage, Transects, Riparian structure, CHaMP method, Peck et al. (2001) methods

abstract: This method is used to measure and estimate the percentage of understory vegetation coverage and percentage of bare ground in a riparian area, which is the zone adjacent to a water body such as a river or a lake. The measurement is taken at ten different plots, five on each bank within a 10m x 10m plot starting from bankfull level. The understory vegetation coverage is visually estimated for each plot and then averaged out to get the overall percentage understory cover. Any area that does not have understory vegetation is considered as 100% no cover. This method follows the CHaMP (Continuous Harvest and Monitoring Program) Riparian Structure Method, which is widely used in environmental monitoring for assessing riparian health. The importance of this method lies in providing valuable information about the structural condition of riparian areas, which can help identify changes or trends over time, aid in decision-making for conservation efforts and management plans, and contribute to understanding the ecological functions of riparian zones. There is no code provided in this explanation as it is a descriptive summary of the method.

description:
The text body provides information on the assessment of understory cover and no cover within a 10m x 10m plot along both banks, using the CHaMP (Consumer Habitat Assessment & Monitoring Program) - Riparian Structure Method. Five transects are established at specific locations (1, 6, 11, 16, 21) starting from bankfull level for each plot.

For every plot, the percentage of understory cover, which lies between 0.5m and 5m height, is visually estimated. The understory cover percentage is then calculated as an average of the estimates obtained from all ten plots. Conversely, the percentage understory no cover is determined by subtracting the percentage understory cover from 100%.

The CHaMP method, as described in detail at http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/845, follows the protocols outlined in Peck et al. (2001), which have been employed by the Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP). This technique focuses on evaluating understory vegetation structure within riparian areas to identify habitat availability for consumers, such as fish.
